message.content:
cs.CL, cs.LG, cs.AI, cs.IR, cs.NE 

This paper is likely to belong to the Natural Language Processing (NLP) subfield of Computer Science, as it deals with word embeddings and context configurations for different word classes. Specifically, it focuses on improving the quality and efficiency of class-specific word representations. Therefore, the most likely sub-category is cs.CL (Computation and Language), which covers NLP and related topics. 

The paper also involves machine learning techniques, such as automatic selection algorithms, which suggests that it could also fit into the sub-categories of cs.LG (Machine Learning) and cs.AI (Artificial Intelligence). 

Furthermore, the paper evaluates its proposed method on a benchmarking dataset, which could place it in the sub-category of cs.IR (Information Retrieval), as similarity scores are often used in information retrieval tasks. 

Finally, the paper mentions the use of dependency-based contexts, which could suggest a connection to the sub-category of cs.NE (Neural and Evolutionary Computing), which covers neural network models and their applications.
